items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday evening. High water at Exmouth is at 9.15pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Low pressure weather conditions are forecast and tide levels are expected to be 0.29m higher than predicted. Some overtopping and spray may be observed along the coast. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 2.23mAOD, this is 0.29m above astronomical tide level.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the lower River Churn as a result of recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue in the Cerney Wick area today, 5 October 2024. No further rain is expected today. River levels are expected to remain high along the river today.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff will be out in the river catchment today checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 6 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is possible.

River levels are high on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 5 October 2024. No further rain is expected today. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 6 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels remain high but have been lowering on the River Thames around Abingdon. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days. No further rain is expected today, 5 October 2024. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 6 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is expected.

Flood warnings are in force for the River Ray at Islip and for the Murcott area. River levels are high but stable on the River Ray, however, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 5 October 2024. No further rain is expected today. River levels are currently stable but are expected to remain high over the next few days and will be sensitive to further rainfall. 

Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 07:45am on Sunday 6th October. 

The causeway at Earith has approximately 20 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has 115 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney as approximately 125 centimetres of water on the road.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 

The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. 

We will update this message by 4pm, Sunday 06/10/2024

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Coln and tributaries as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land and roads is expected, especially in the Fairford area. No further rain is expected today, 5 October 2024. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days, and will be sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 6 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are still high but continuing to fall on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Saturday 5 October.
No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.
We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
The rest of today, Saturday 5 October, is forecast to remain dry but further rainfall is possible on Sunday 6 October, which could push river levels back up again.
As river levels remain high and we are not expecting much change in the level at the Staines Moor gauge, this message will continue to be updated once per day. 
This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Sunday 6 October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 06/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End throughout today, Saturday 5 October 2024 and into tomorrow. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 06/10/2024, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days that may cause rivers to rise again. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 5pm on 06/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.

Further light rainfall is forecast today and in the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high until later today, 06/10/24.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 06/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 06/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are now falling on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is still possible through Saturday and into Sunday. Property flooding is not expected.

Flooding may affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected from Saturday onwards and the situation should improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 12:00 Midday on 06/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are steadily falling. The forecast is dry today but unsettled from Sunday into next week. 

There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely and the forecast for Sunday onwards. We will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: River levels in the River Nene remain high as a result of recent rainfall in the Middle Nene area, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts also indicate that further flooding inside properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued.  We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 06/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high and are responsive to further rainfall. Based on the current forecast, flooding is still possible for the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly.  The forecast is for scattered showers today and then potential for heavier rainfall on Monday and throughout this week. Further rainfall will keep river levels high or could potentially see them rise again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, Sunday 06/10/24.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
River Ivel in Hertfordshire and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: River levels have fallen along the Ivel. This alert is in force due to particular concerns for the area downstream of Biggleswade. Based on the current forecast, flooding here is still possible for the next few days.  Areas most at risk are around the River Ivel from Langford to Blunham, including the rivers Purwell, Hiz, Flit and Hit.  The forecast is for scattered showers today and then potential for heavier rainfall on Monday and throughout this week. Further rainfall could see river levels rise again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm this afternoon, Sunday 06/10/24.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are slowly falling at the Brentingby Dam river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston.   
No further rainfall is forecast We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 06/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are continuing to fall but remain responsive to further rainfall. Based on the current forecast, flooding is still possible for several days as floodwater moves down the catchment from upstream of Bedford. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Wyboston to the south of Brampton, including Duloe Brook, Hen Brook and Fox Brook. The forecast is for scattered showers today and then potential for heavier rainfall on Monday and throughout this week. Further rainfall will keep river levels high or could potentially see them rise again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, Sunday, 06/10/24.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:
Property flooding is possible.

River levels are high but steady on the River Ray. Therefore flooding of properties, low lying land and roads is expected to continue this evening, 5 October 2024. Areas most at risk are properties closest to the river in Islip and surrounding villages. River levels are expected to remain steady today, but further rainfall is possible early next week which may lead to increases in river levels. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water and do not drive along flooded roads. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 6 October 2024, or as the situation changes.
